testCases.explanation: Node 5 is in the left subtree and node 1 is in the right subtree of node 3. So node 3 is their LCA.
Node 4 is a descendant of node 5 (via node 2). A node can be a descendant of itself, so LCA is node 5.
Node 2 is a child of node 1. Node 1 is an ancestor of node 2 and also node 1 itself, so LCA is node 1.
Node 5 is the left child and node 1 is the right child of node 3. Their LCA is node 3 (the root).
Both node 6 and node 2 are children of node 5. Their LCA is node 5.

description: Given a binary tree, find the lowest common ancestor (LCA) of two given nodes p and q. The LCA is defined as the lowest node in the tree that has both p and q as descendants (a node can be a descendant of itself). Return the value of the LCA node.

examples.explanation: The LCA of nodes 5 and 1 is node 3.
The LCA of nodes 5 and 4 is node 5, since a node can be a descendant of itself.

constraints: The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [2, 10^5]
p and q will exist in the tree
